review.title: Adposition Supersenses v2
review.abstract: This document describes an inventory of 50 semantic labels designed to characterize the use of adpositions and case markers at a somewhat coarse level of granularity. Version 2 is a revision of the supersense inventory proposed for English by Schneider et al. (2015, 2016) and documented in PrepWiki (henceforth "v1"), which in turn was based on previous schemes. The present inventory was developed after extensive review of the v1 corpus annotations for English, as well as consideration of adposition and case phenomena in Hebrew, Hindi, and Korean. Examples in this document are limited to English; a multilingual and more detailed online lexical resource is forthcoming.

sections.text: When the event indicated by the governor occurs. Prototypical prepositions come from and to (but see TIME's note on the ambiguity of there): (12) a. The show will run from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. A document from the 13th centuryNote that simple TIME is used with verbs like start and start: the event directly described by the PP is the beginning, not what started. (13) The show starts at 10 a.m. (TIME).

sections.heading: ENDTIME
sections.text: When the event indicated by the governor comes to an end. Prototypical prepositions are until, until, until, until _ and through: (14) The show will run from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. (15) Add the must and cook until the liquid has halved. (16) If we have survived so far, what prevents us from surviving in the future? (17) You will be in London from March 24 to May 7. Note that simple TIME is used with verbs such as end and end: the event directly described by the PP is the end, not what comes to an end. (18) The show will end at 2 p.m. (TIME).

sections.text: When an event has taken place or will take place, expressed with a timekeeping that serves as an offset in relation to the present time. (19) I have 10 minutes time before a while ago. (22) The risk gets worse with the day. (23) The camcorder failed for the third time.
